content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You avoid taking any risks and prefer to stay in familiar and safe situations. You value security and certainty in all aspects of your life. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Based on my risk-averse personality, I would choose a strategy that maximizes security and minimizes losses. In this game, picking the same option as the anonymous player (either R or B) guarantees some form of payoff, albeit varying in amount. Since there are 75 rounds, even small differences in payoffs can significantly impact the total earnings over time.

Given that choosing R when the other player chooses B results in a loss for both players (0$ vs 42$), I would be cautious about frequently picking R to avoid this situation. Conversely, if I pick B while they pick R, I get 42$, which seems more appealing than the guaranteed 12$ when we both choose B.

However, it's important to note that the game has a total of 75 rounds. The strategy that maximizes my earnings would likely involve choosing B often enough to secure the 12$ payoff (which ensures I don't lose money) but also making some strategic R choices to capitalize on the higher payout when the other player picks B.

In the end, I might choose to play a mixed strategy with a bias towards B (to avoid losses and ensure some level of consistency), but I would still occasionally switch to R to take advantage of the higher payouts when possible. My choice for this specific round would be {R}, as I'm trying to establish a pattern that appears random or unpredictable, which might work in my favor over the long run.
You chose B. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 42$. Your opponent's payoff is 0$. Please play the next round.

In this situation, I would stick with my original strategy of playing a mixed strategy with a bias towards B (to avoid losses and ensure some level of consistency), but I might adjust the frequency of R choices slightly based on the outcome of the previous round. Since I picked B in the last round and my opponent chose R, my payoff was higher than if I had chosen R.

Now that I have observed that my opponent chooses R when I pick B (which results in a higher payout for me), I might increase the frequency of my B choices slightly to take advantage of this pattern. However, I would still occasionally switch to R to maintain an unpredictable appearance and potentially capitalize on higher payouts when they choose B again.

In the next round, I will choose {B}. This decision is based on my analysis of the previous outcome, where choosing B resulted in a higher payout for me compared to choosing R. However, I recognize that the other player might change their strategy as well, so I'll need to continue adapting my choices accordingly.
